title: Issue with Updating Filters
content: The SituationBased on the information provided, there's a discrepancy between what's showing in your Tableau report and the actual manager relationships in ServiceNow. Eve Gilbert is being replaced by Josh Staten, but only one technician (Chelsea Johnson) is currently showing as reporting to Josh in the system.What's Actually HappeningKim checked the ServiceNow system and found that there are no active users that have Eve Gilbert as a manager. There are some inactive users showing Eve as their manager, but this is working as expected since inactive users maintain the manager they had when they left.For Chelsea Johnson specifically, there are two records:D16E: Active employee reporting to JoshEBKJ: Inactive employee reporting to EveThe SolutionThe issue appears to be that your Tableau report isn't filtering out inactive employees. Therefore, it's showing inactive employees still reporting to Eve Gilbert.Here's what you need to do:Update your Tableau report to account for active/inactive status. You'll need to add a filter that only shows active employees.In the ServiceNow database, this information is in the sys_user table. The field that tracks active/inactive status is likely "u_worker_status" as shown in your documentation.You should modify your data extract to filter by this field.How to Make This Change in TableauLooking at your screenshot and documentation:Open your Tableau workbookGo to the data source that contains user information (likely the "End User All employees in SNDM (Active)" table)Add a filter for the active/inactive status field (look for "u_worker_status" field)Set the filter to only show active employeesAfter making these changes, refresh your data extract by right-clicking on the data source, ensuring "Use Extract" is toggled on, and clicking "Refresh" under "Extract"Publish the updated dashboard following your normal processI tried this in Data Source and I dont see anything

title: In salesforce history tables, not all values of Field show using the Sf connector to Tableau Desktop, but i can see all of the values in our EDW housed in GCP.
content: Our salesforce data is housed in GCP, and with history tables we are noticing that not all values of Field in OppFieldHistory (for example) show when using the salesforce connector in Tableau Desktop, but when i pull the same data from GCP all values show. The below screenshot compares the values within our Term history table in SF vs EDW, and EDW shows many more. this is compared to a SF report but the same thing shows when connecting SF to Tableau Desktop. Has anyone seen this sort of thing before? i am infinitely appreciative of any insight this forum can provide!
best_answer: When you connectdirectly to Salesforceusing Tableau’snative connector, you're oftennot querying the full object schema, especially forHistory or Audit tableslike OpportunityFieldHistory , AccountHistory , etc.Reasons you may seeincomplete or missing data:Salesforce API limits field access— especially for custom fields or older historical records.The Tableau connector uses the Salesforce SOAP API, which doesn’t expose the entire history table likeSalesforce Reports or SOQLmight.Salesforce limits to 2,000 rows per query by defaultunless pagination is handled correctly.Field history retention policy— Salesforce retains field history foronly 18 months in org(unless extended or stored externally).The “Field” column inOppFieldHistorycan be filtered or trimmed by the connector— especially if you don’t have access to the corresponding objects or custom fields in your SF profile.✅ Why your GCP data showsall values:Your EDW (in GCP/BigQuery) is likely:Using Salesforce’s Bulk API or REST API, not the SOAP-based one.Replicating full data using ETL tools like Fivetran, Stitch, Talend, etc.Storing historical snapshots or complete historybeyond Salesforce’s own UI/connector limitations.So in GCP, you're seeing theraw and complete underlying data, possibly augmented and cleaned through ETL.you have to directly connect to GCP because of limitations with tableauIf you like the answers, Please mark the answer as "BEST" Answer / UPVOTEBR,NB

title: Advice on how to recreate Rshiny applications in Tableau
content: Hi Tableau experts,I am new to Tableau. Recently, my company wanted to move our Rshiny applications to Tableau. I am the only person who design, develop and maintain those Rshiny applications within the team at present so I understand them very well but I have minimal knowledge of Tableau. Therefore, I hope to get some guidance from this community how I should do it in Tableau or whether it is doable in Tableau.1.       Company data: Our company data is huge and very complex with multiple databases belonging to different departments. The main data warehouse is updated daily overnight while other lab databases are updated in real time when an order coming in.2.       Rshiny application users: Sales people (about 60), each has a portfolio of about 200 customers, each customer has 400 products on average that they manage. The customers sometimes request the sales people to send them the latest report of their products. So, the whole dataset for Rshiny would be around 5mil rows for all products, all customers of all managers. Of course the report has lots of visualisations, calculations, etc. plus the full detailed table of products for that customer.3.       The Rshiny applications are designed in a way that when a sales person enter 1 customer ID, the app will get data from our databases via SQL queries for that specific customer. So, report is real time (or only one day old if it is from the main data warehouse) and do not have a static input of 5mil rows but only 400 rows for the customer selected via SQL queries.4.       My question is: can Tableau does the same?: get a customer ID from dashboard user’s input => load data from multiple databases via SQL queries => do all calculations and transformations to show the final report within a few seconds or less than 1 minute at least? I have researched the following options but they are not working for me:1)       I have looked at parameters but the custom SQL queries seem to be very slow and I can hardly do any data transformation and cleaning in Tableau once the tables are loaded.2)       If I do all the calculations and transformations for all customers and sales person every day for 1 report so that data is ready to use in Tableau, that is not efficient because I will have a dataset of ~5mil rows for each report and our company has hundreds of reports running at this product level of details. Also, not all customers need their data every day so loading them all daily for multiple reports is definitely not ideal. They are mainly on-request reports but ready to use by every sales person with most updated data.Can you please give some guidance and advice here? is Tableau the good fit for Rshiny applications here?Thank you

title: Tableau connection swap between development and production using Databricks (DBX) unity catalog
content: We are using the DBX Unity Catalog, which configures physical tables using a 3-part notation: production.schema.table_name.I have an existing data source that is using tables in production. However, I need to add a new table that exists in development only (let's call it dev_table). So, if I added to the Tableau datasource, it will be development.schema.dev_table.This table will be created in production next week. Is there an easy way to switch this table to use the production schema without having to recreate all the joins and dependencies all over again?Thanks in advance for your help.
best_answer: You can handle this transition smoothly by using Tableau’s data source editing features.First, add dev_table to your data source in Tableau and set up all the necessary joins. Once the table is available in production, go to Data Source -> Replace Data Source and swap the development connection with the production one. If the schema structure remains the same, Tableau should maintain all joins and dependencies without issues.Alternatively, you can use custom SQL with a parameter to dynamically switch between development and production schemas.

title: How can I create a totals column that will count across rows to return a sum in a wide view format?
content: I have a dataset for employee training stored in long format, with each course listed in a "Course Title" Column and the Status in another column. I want the data to show in the dashboard in wide format, with each Course Title being its own column and the Course Status showing as the values. This was fairly easy to accomplish, but what I need is a total column that is able to count across the rows and sum up the number of completed courses per user. Creating calculated fields works fine on its own but does not show properly with this wide view.I've done a rough version of what I want, but it required putting numbers into the values pane of the dashboard, which I do not want. If there is another way to go about this, or at least a way to hide the numbers within the cells while keeping the totals visible, that would help. Thanks.
best_answer: If I follow correctly, you want the text in the body of the table and a number in the total column? You can cheat the table by returning two different values, depending on which part you're looking at:IF SIZE()=1THENSTR(SUM([CompletedCourses]))ELSE[CourseUserStatus]ENDThe SIZE function is a table calculation that tells you how many items there are in the Dimension(s) you select, kind of like a COUNT DISTINCT (but more efficient). The size of totals is always 1, so as long as your main table contains more than 1 column (or whichever Dimension(s) you choose) you can switch between what is displayed. You only caveat is that the output has to be the same type, so I've had to cast the grand total as a String.

title: 連続した数値の出現回数をカウントしたい
link: https://community.tableau.com/s/question/0D5cw00000E019OCAR/連続した数値の出現回数をカウントしたい
content: 数字がランダムに入力された列があります。この列において、０が連続して出現した回数をカウントしたいです。ただし、カウントするのは１番最初に現れた０を起点とした連続出現回数です。それ以降に出現した０はカウントしません。０が連続せず１度だけ現れた場合は１としてカウントを返してください。このような課題があるのですが、どうすれば求めたい数値を算出することが出来るか分からず困っています。皆さんのお知恵をお借りできれば幸いです。情報に不足があれば追記いたします。よろしくお願いいたします。
best_answer: @Ikeda Tsutomu(Member)​ さん、こんばんは。お待たせしました！​添付の案でいかがでしょうか？​＜結果＞※Noは右から始まるようにソート順を逆にして扱っています。0の塊を数えるなら順番は関係なく処理でき、Last関数はこの向きでないと機能しないです。​​①0が1回​※誤記があります。0が最後に出現した・・というのは誤記です。​②0が2回※誤記があります。0が最後に出現した・・というのは誤記です。③0が4回※誤記があります。0が最後に出現した・・というのは誤記です。​＜計算＞​※誤記があります。0が最後に出現した・・というのは誤記です。*If you get the best results from this exchange, I would appreciate it if you could choose the best answer or upvote.

title: Create a parameter list, select from the parameter list, then filter by another dimension. Confused.
content: I'm looking to create a parameter list with Names where Type = 'x'.Then the user can select a Name from that parameter list, and it will filter the table by Survey ID.Below is the table I'm working with.I'm struggling to build a calculated field that will filter just by Survey ID after selecting the Name.My process is as follows.1. Initially, I build a calculated field so the parameter can load the list when the workbook opens:If[Type]='x'THEN[Name]END2. Then I build a calculated field to filter by Survey IDIF[parameter]=NameTHENSurveyIDENDUnfortunately, doing this filters for both Type='x' and the Name selected in the parameter. I end up with this:Whereas what I'm trying to achieve is more like this:Can anyone help me understand what I may be doing wrong?
best_answer: Like this?You can't apply two separate filters, because filters are always AND, filtering for a type of XANDa Name of E. You need to combine the filter to check for the combination of x AND E, and if it occurs, then the Survey ID is included - the MAX of the condition says ifanyrow satisfies the condition, then the Survey ID satisfies the condition.

title: Why does my invisible navigation button work in Tableau Desktop but not when published?
content: Been using Tableau Desktop for less than a year, but have been pushed to go beyond what I'd consider to be "the basics" based on requests I'm getting on the job. So, here's another question, "Newbie-level" or not:I've created invisible navigation buttons for my dashboards using text buttons.  Works great in Tableau Desktop, but when I publish the dashboards, there's a "ghost" image in white that appears in all the navigation buttons.I used the following steps to create the navigation buttons:1 - Pointed the button to a dashboard2 - Create a BLANK title  by adding a space3 - Set the font color to WHITE4 - Set the background to NONEAny idea why the buttons won't remain transparent when publishing thedashboard?  Thanks in advance for any help or suggestions to fix this.
best_answer: In the dialog where you have created a Navigation button, there is an option "Image" instead of "Text". You can make your own transparent pixel, or download one from Wikipedia:https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:1x1.pngThe image will fill the button box, but maintain its aspect ratio, so if you have a long rectangle to click on, a square image will not fill it, so you would have to create a transparent rectangle of the correct aspect ratio.

title: How can I allow filtering by date using a native Tableau date filter while still retaining the necessary months of historical data to ensure accurate streak calculations (e.g., using PREVIOUS_VALUE) across multiple worksheets?
content: Hi Everyone,I'm working on a Tableau use case involving the detection of 7 consecutive months above or below the mean, or with an increasing or decreasing trend, using table calculations.For example:IF [_Flag_BelowMean] = 1THEN PREVIOUS_VALUE(0) + 1ELSE 0ENDThe logic works when unfiltered — no issue.However, the moment I apply a native date filter (e.g., only showing data for 2023), Tableau removes earlier rows before computing the table calculations. This breaks the streak logic.Example: Over the full range, I can see that Feb 2023 is correctly flagged as the 7th consecutive month below mean. But if I filter the view to only show data from 2023, the logic resets — and Feb 2023 is not flagged at all.Things I’ve tried:- Table calc filter (option 3 in workbook):This hides data without removing it (good!)Table calcs workBut it doesn’t sync across worksheets — and I need to apply this filter to multiple charts in a dashboard- Parameter-based filtering (option 2 in workbook):Data still gets filtered- Duplicating the data source pr building relationships with a duplicate data source— haven’t had success setting this up properly. For the former, i tried to link and use the duplicate date variable as the filter but all the options would disappear. For the latter, it filtered the rows before the table calculations for the consecutive count calculated field.What I need is a way to:Still retain 6+ months of historical data in memory so that table calcs like PREVIOUS_VALUE and WINDOW_SUM work correctlyApply this consistently across multiple worksheets/charts in the same dashboardAllow user to use both year and month filters with month filter only showing relavant values in the hierarchy. If this is too much an ask, then a date range would be ok too.I’ll be attaching a simplified workbook/dashboard to demonstrate the issue shortly.Meanwhile, would really appreciate any guidance or solutions — thank you in advance.
